First, more trouble for the American dollar today, and concern about worse to come, maybe much worse.
The dollar is down against the Euro, the Canadian dollar, the Australian dollar and the Japanese Yen.
This began overnight with a published remark from a Chinese official.
He said his country may move some of its huge cash reserves out of dollars and into euros.
One official, one remark, and the Euro hit new highs against the dollar.
It was more than $1.47 for a while.
Here with us is Robert Flint.
He is former China bureau chief for The Wall Street Journal, where he's now news editor.
Robert Flint, who is this Chinese official and what was it he said exactly?
He's the vice chairman of the legislative body in China and he is a rather colorful politician there.
There are no loose canons in China, but he's the closest thing that you can come to it.
However, he does not have a direct role in monetary or currency policy.
His name is Cheng Siwei.
Cheng Siwei, yeah.
Cheng Siwei.
Thank you.
Well, tell me - how is it that this remark of his set off such a flurry of trading then?

Well, for one thing, until the State Council, which is the highest executive body and directly controlled by the Chinese Communist Party, until they finally issue some statement, it's not really, you know, of great impact to what other officials would say.
It's not over in China until the State Council sings, so to say.

And the other thing is, markets are just exceptionally nervous, and any kind of statement that they don't really understand or it has big implications for them, because investors are so unsure, they'll react with a little bit of panic, and there's was a lot, a lot, a lot of the dollar selling overnight.
Well, when you saw this, did you think maybe it's a trial balloon, maybe China's...
I certainly think that that's a possibility.
